direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know ... Three, four weeks.

direction.raw_text: Much less than that. (checks his watch) An hour and a half. David looks at him uneasily. Dick Van Dyke flashes a broad nasty smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See--and this is really great-- the show was on for what--half an hour a week? So that means for every week that goes by in Pleasantville, only half an hour goes by in the real world. The smile gets bigger. Dick Van Dyke moves closer to him.

direction.raw_text: Now Buddy, you're going on trial tomorrow. And if they find you guilty, you're gonna be stuck here forever. Well, not forever--lemme think ... (calculates) Five year sentence ... Carry the three ... That comes out to ... sixteen and a half centuries, and that's rounding down.

direction.raw_text: I'm going on trial tomorrow?

direction.raw_text: This is TV pal. They don't fool around. David is rocked but tries not to show it.

direction.raw_text: There's worse places.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh sure. For the first hundred years. Then it starts to get a little monotonous. (beat) Sleep well. He taps on the bars for Dan who opens the lock and lets him out. The door CLANGS shut as the two of them disappear down the hall. The minute they are gone, the stoicism falls. David looks around his cell, truly afraid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R. He stares at the tiny cot ... The plain light bulb in the ceiling ... The single pillow with the plastic covering it ... Forever is starting to look like a long time. David crosses to the small window and looks out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . OUT THE WINDOW. Across the town square he can see the side of the Town Hall complete with the newly painted mural. The "Utopian" view of Pleasantville is just as he left it with one notable exception: The edges of painting are starting to turn back to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. It is bathed in sunlight. Dozens of people stream through the front door for the first trial in Pleasantville's history. There is a weird carnival atmosphere in the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. The place has been transformed from the Chamber of Commerce meeting hall to a small town courtroom, complete with pews and ceiling fans. The only carry over from its previous configuration is the huge CHAMBER OF COMMERCE banner draped across the back wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BENCH. At the center of the courtroom where the podium used to be is a large, elevated judge's bench with a Rotary insignia on the front. Big Bob sits six or seven feet above the proceedings finally living up to his name. The whole thing is a strange combination of Franz Kafka and "Inherit the Wind." Big Bob bangs the gavel ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R. The undertone begins to quiet down. All of the faces in the pews are Black and White. There is a "colored" section in the back for standing room only.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . JURORS BOX. George is seated in the front row of the jury, despite his relationship to one of the defendants. He is dressed impeccably with his Rotary Pin still gleaming on his lapel. After a moment or two he sneaks a glance toward the back of the room ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BETTY. She stands in the back with the rest of the "colored" faces. Betty cranes her head to catch a glimpse of David or Mr. Johnson. All at once, a hush goes through the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DOORWAY. It swings open and David and Mr. Johnson are led in wearing handcuffs. Dan, the Police Chief (now ballif), shows them to a table in the center of the room directly facing Big Bob. There is no lawyer present. There is also no prosecutor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAVID. He glances around a little confused. (Weird courtroom.) Big Bob bangs the gavel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud Parker and William Johnson, you have been charged with desecration of a public building and the intentional use of prohibited paint colors in violation of the Pleasantville Code of Conduct and laws of common decency. Do you admit that on the night of May 1, you did consciously and willfully apply the following FORBIDDEN colors to the Pleasantville Town Hall: (beat) Red, Pink, Vermillion, Puce, Chartreuse, Umber, Blue, Aqua, Ox Blood, Green, Peach, Crimson, Yellow, Olive and Magenta.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um ... Yes I do. Where's our lawyer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We prefer to keep these proceedings as "pleasant" as possible. I don't think a lawyer will be necessary. There is a murmur and a great deal of nodding amongst the black and white faces. Big Bob smiles to himself then proceeds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you further admit that this was done surreptitiously and under the cover of darkness?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well--it was dark out ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. Do you further admit that this unnatural depiction occurred in full public view where it was accessible to, and in plain sight of, minor children?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was accessible to everyone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very well. Let the record show that the defendants have answered in the affirmative to all the charges. He looks directly at them for the first time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have anything to say in your defense?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DEFENSE TABLE. Mr. Johnson just looks at David, confused and terrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn`t mean to hurt anybody. I just have to paint ... I need to. He gropes for something else to say, but what else is there? David glances over and sees him sit slowly back in his seat. David rises from his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I've got something to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very well ... David looks out over the audience. After a moment or two, he looks back at Big Bob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I know why you're doing this. I mean, I understand why you're doing this. I used to feel the same way. I used to want this place to stay just the way it was. I never wanted it to change ... There is a loud MURMUR. Big Bob bangs the gavel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But nothing stays the same. You get things, and you lose things, and that's the good part and the bad part--but you can't have a good part without a bad part. He turns and sees his mother in the balcony. They lock eyes for a moment. David smiles slightly and continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's like the basketball team.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The basketball team?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. Everybody's upset because they're not winning anymore--but just think how it would feel if all of a sudden they do win. There's a murmur in the gallery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wouldn't it feel better than when they used to win all the time? There is a LOUDER MURMUR. Big Bob looks concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See, I know you want it to stay "Pleasant" but there are so many things that are so much better: like Silly ... or Sexy ... or Dangerous ... or Wild ... or Brief ... (beat) And every one of those things is in you all the time if you just have the guts to look for them. (pointing to the "colored" section) Look at those faces back there. They're no different than you are. They just happened to see something inside themselves that you don't want to ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay--that's enough!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought I was allowed to defend myself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not allowed to lie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not lying ... Here I'll show you. He turns suddenly toward the jury box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Simpson ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What color is that hedge of yours?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Green.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, not that hedge. The other one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other one?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The one in your mind. The one that you see on a bright cold morning. The one that you see when you walk in front of your house and you just stand there and stare. Mr. Simpson suddenly looks far away. He gets a kind of dreamy look in his eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What color is that hedge?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: UP. MR. SIMPSON.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SIMPSON TURNS TO LIVING COLOR. A huge MURMUR moves through the courtroom. Bob bangs the gavel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said, that's enough!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "No ... Let him finish ... Go on ..." Big Bob lifts the gavel and is about to bang it when David suddenly turns toward George.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright. Dad ...
direction.name: direction

result.heading: SUDDENLY AND BEFORE OUR EYES, MR

direction.raw_text: . There is a LOUDER MURMUR. Big Bob just looks at him frozen while David confronts his "father." George straightens up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes Bud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you miss her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: UP. GEORGE. He looks at him stunned. Big Bob bangs the gavel but nobody listens. George just stares at him like he got shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean, of course you do, but it isn't just the cooking or the cleaning that you miss--it's something else, isn't it ... George swallows. The UNDERTONE in the room starts to grow as he glances toward the back of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe you can't even describe it. Maybe you only know it when it's gone. Maybe it's like there's a whole piece of you that's missing too. (shrugs) You might even call it "love."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, that's IT!!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now don't you think she looks just as pretty in color? Don't you think she looks just as pretty as she did the day you met her? Slowly, almost imperceptibly George nods. A single tear rolls down his cheek. As it traces the side of his face it leaves a long trail of COLOR behind it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you wish you could tell her that? He nods again and it all comes out. Betty smiles at him through her tears. Even Mr. Johnson smiles as well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why am I out of order?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well I don't think it's a circus. And I don't think they do either. David motions behind him to the black and white section. There are now ten to fifteen "colored" faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But see that's just the point. It can't stop at once. Because it's in you. And you can't stop something that's in you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not in ME.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh sure it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No it isn't. He crosses to the bench looking right up at Big Bob. He leans over the bench and gets right up in his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want to do to me right now? Big Bob starts to tremble. He shakes with rage as David moves closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon. Everyone's turning colors. Kids are making out in the street. No one's getting their dinner-- hell, you could have a flood any minute ... Pretty soon you could have the women going off to work while the men stayed home and cooked ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not going to happen!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it could happen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No it couldn't! Big Bob looks at David and starts to tremble. It starts around the base of his neck, spreads quickly up the rest of his head. After a moment or two, Big Bob has gone completely
direction.name: direction

result.heading: BOB BECAUSE I WILL NOT ALLOW YOU TO TURN THIS COURTROOM INTO A CIRCUS
BOB THIS BEHAVIOR WILL STOP AT ONCE

direction.raw_text: R. A gasp goes through the courtroom. David looks at him and just smiles. The crowd reaction turns almost to a ROAR as Big Bob turns and catches his reflection in the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: UP. BIG BOB. He sees the ruddy image staring back at him, then looks down at his hands. They have gone completely RED as well. Big Bob freezes for an instant then bolts from the bench in panic and flees the room--flinging open the doors to the courtroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DOORWAY. As Big Bob flees, he reveals an amazing sight: the Town Square GLISTENS IN LIVING COLOR. The huge lawn is a rich deep green. The sky is a dense opaque blue. Dozens of spectators bolt from their seats and rush to the doorway as the crowd moves outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . (FULL COLOR!) All the birds are really chirping. Red Brick, Yellow cars, Green hats ... The barber pole in front of Gus' has finally turned to red, white and blue--he can't help smiling. David walks out into the sunlight and stares in wonder at his creation. The whole town is washed in joy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R. Margaret comes up and throws her arms around him. They meet in a rich passionate kiss (in direct defiance of the code of conduct). Several people around them actually clap, like spectators at a wedding. Jennifer moves up next to them and looks at her brother making out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uch ... I am like gonna hurl ... David turns and looks at her. Both of them laugh. David throws his arms around his sister as more and more people stream out of the courtroom into the sunlight ...

direction.raw_text: . DAY. David and Jennifer stand together on the edge of town. She clutches a valise in her hand. He holds the remote control.

direction.raw_text: Are you sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you. I'm like positive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This thing works. We could go home right now.

direction.raw_text: I'm not ready yet. I gotta do this for a little while.

Jennifer is dressed in Mary Sue's clothes with a little bit of style thrown in. Rich fields of wheat spread out in the distance.

direction.raw_text: Besides. You think there's like a chance I'm gonna get into college back there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honestly ... no. They both smile.

direction.raw_text: You got the admissions letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right here.

direction.raw_text: And you're sure about this?

direction.raw_text: I've done the slut thing, David. It's really kinda old. David nods.

direction.raw_text: I'll come back and check on you in a month. Jennifer nods and gives him a hug. She holds on tight for a couple of seconds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're like the coolest brother in the world. David smiles. Never been called cool before. They suddenly hear the SOUND of a motor and look to their left. A huge Greyhound bus lumbers up the highway, pulling to a halt at the sign. The doors open beckoning her in. Jennifer smiles at her brother, then turns toward the door ...

direction.raw_text: . DAY. She clutches her umbrella at her side. David holds a bag of oatmeal cookies. Each one clings on to the other one's clothing. Their faces are inches apart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're gonna forget about me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No I won't. I swear. Margaret nods. She looks at him for a moment then wraps her arms around his neck. They meet in a long, rich, wet, soft kiss. The umbrella falls to the ground ...

direction.raw_text: I like calling you David.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like it too.

direction.raw_text: . David stands in front of the television with Mr. Johnson at his side. He holds the remote control in his hand. Mr. Johnson seems pretty amazed at the whole idea.

direction.raw_text: Well how do you know it won't go back to the way it was?

direction.raw_text: Oh. (reaching into his pocket) I've got something for you. He pulls out a folded piece of paper. Mr. Johnson extends it to David who unfolds it and instantly smiles.

direction.raw_text: . PAPER. It is a small painted replica of their mural in the same vibrant colors. Everything is scaled perfectly, exactly like the one on the wall.

direction.raw_text: . DAVID.

direction.raw_text: It's beautiful.

direction.raw_text: Just a little--You know. David looks up at him and smiles. All at once he glances toward the door.

direction.raw_text: I made you these for the trip. They're marshmallow rice squares.

direction.raw_text: Thanks. I thought you weren't gonna ...

direction.raw_text: I'm so proud of you, Bud.

direction.raw_text: Thanks ... I love you.

direction.raw_text: Well ... She steps back and looks at him. David glances down at the remote.

direction.raw_text: . DAY. All the ersatz Spanish houses stretch out toward infinity. A WESTEC security patrol cruises by them at a crawl. A second or two later, all the sprinklers turn on in uniform synchronization.
